segment.source: This topic helps you interpret the results produced by the On/Off assessments (Boot Performance (Fast Startup), Boot Performance (Full Boot), Standby Performance, and Hibernate Performance).
segment.target: This topic helps you interpret the results produced by the On/Off assessments (Boot Performance (Fast Startup), Boot Performance (Full Boot), Standby Performance, and Hibernate Performance).

segment.source: It also provides guidance on how to use the results to identify and resolve several common issues that negatively impact the end user’s experience when shutting down and booting a computer.
segment.target: It also provides guidance on how to use the results to identify and resolve several common issues that negatively impact the end user’s experience when shutting down and booting a computer.

segment.source: Goals File
segment.target: Goals File

segment.source: You can create custom goals to measure your improvements in the Results View.
segment.target: You can create custom goals to measure your improvements in the Results View.

segment.source: Goals files are a triage tool that can help you understand how a PC is performing and to compare PCs in your business.
segment.target: Goals files are a triage tool that can help you understand how a PC is performing and to compare PCs in your business.

segment.source: For example, goals for a basic laptop might be different than the goals you set for a high end desktop computer, or market expectations might change in such a way that you want the flexibility to define different goals and key requirements as time passes and technology improves.
segment.target: For example, goals for a basic laptop might be different than the goals you set for a high end desktop computer, or market expectations might change in such a way that you want the flexibility to define different goals and key requirements as time passes and technology improves.

segment.source: When a metric value is compared to the goal for that metric, the status is color coded in the Result View as follows:
segment.target: When a metric value is compared to the goal for that metric, the status is color coded in the Result View as follows:

segment.source: Light purple means that the system has a great user experience and that there are no perceived problems.
segment.target: Light purple means that the system has a great user experience and that there are no perceived problems.

segment.source: Medium purple means that the user experience is tolerable and you can optimize the system.
segment.target: Medium purple means that the user experience is tolerable and you can optimize the system.

segment.source: Review the recommendations and analysis to see what improvements can be made to the system.
segment.target: Review the recommendations and analysis to see what improvements can be made to the system.

segment.source: These can be software changes, configuration changes or hardware changes.
segment.target: These can be software changes, configuration changes or hardware changes.

segment.source: Dark purple means that the system has a poor user experience and that there is significant room for improvements.
segment.target: Dark purple means that the system has a poor user experience and that there is significant room for improvements.

segment.source: Review the recommendations and analysis to see the improvements that can be made to the system.
segment.target: Review the recommendations and analysis to see the improvements that can be made to the system.

segment.source: These can be software changes, configuration changes or hardware changes.
segment.target: These can be software changes, configuration changes or hardware changes.

segment.source: You might have to consider making tradeoffs to deliver a high quality Windows experience.
segment.target: You might have to consider making tradeoffs to deliver a high quality Windows experience.

segment.source: No color means that there are no goals defined for the metric.
segment.target: No color means that there are no goals defined for the metric.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: In the Windows Assessment Toolkit for Windows 8, some assessments include default goals files.
segment.target: In the Windows Assessment Toolkit for Windows 8, some assessments include default goals files.

segment.source: The first time you view results using this version of the tools, the default goals file is used.
segment.target: The first time you view results using this version of the tools, the default goals file is used.

segment.source: However, you can also define custom goals for Windows 8 the same way that you can for Windows 8.1 and Windows 10.
segment.target: However, you can also define custom goals for Windows 8 the same way that you can for Windows 8.1 and Windows 10.

segment.source: You can set the goals file location and add a goals file to that location before you can use the UI to apply the custom goals.
segment.target: You can set the goals file location and add a goals file to that location before you can use the UI to apply the custom goals.

segment.source: Once a goals file is selected it will continue to be the goals file that is used for any results that are opened.
segment.target: Once a goals file is selected it will continue to be the goals file that is used for any results that are opened.

segment.source: Only one goals file can be used at a time.
segment.target: Only one goals file can be used at a time.

segment.source: Goals for all assessments are set in a single goals file.
segment.target: Goals for all assessments are set in a single goals file.

segment.source: The assessment tools will search for goals in the following order:
segment.target: The assessment tools will search for goals in the following order:

segment.source: A custom goals file
segment.target: A custom goals file

segment.source: Goals that are defined in the results file
segment.target: Goals that are defined in the results file

segment.source: Goals that are defined in the assessment manifest
segment.target: Goals that are defined in the assessment manifest

segment.source: You can use the sample goals file that is provided at %PROGRAMFILES%Windows Kits10Assessment and Deployment KitWindows Assessment ToolkitSDKSamplesGoals to create your own goals file.
segment.target: You can use the sample goals file that is provided at %PROGRAMFILES%Windows Kits10Assessment and Deployment KitWindows Assessment ToolkitSDKSamplesGoals to create your own goals file.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: You cannot package a goals file with a job, but you can store it on a share for others to use.
segment.target: You cannot package a goals file with a job, but you can store it on a share for others to use.

segment.source: This metric measures the time that the computer spends in shut-down or suspend operations.
segment.target: This metric measures the time that the computer spends in shut-down or suspend operations.

segment.source: The following table describes the metric for each assessment:
segment.target: The following table describes the metric for each assessment:

segment.source: Assessment
segment.target: Assessment

segment.source: Metric Description
segment.target: Metric Description

segment.source: Boot Performance (Fast Startup) Assessment
segment.target: Boot Performance (Fast Startup) Assessment

segment.source: This metric captures the time from the start of the shutdown phase, to the end of writing the hiberfile to disk and the transition to a lower power state (S4).
segment.target: This metric captures the time from the start of the shutdown phase, to the end of writing the hiberfile to disk and the transition to a lower power state (S4).

segment.source: Boot Performance (Full Boot) Assessment
segment.target: Boot Performance (Full Boot) Assessment

segment.source: This metric captures the time from the start of the shutdown phase to the transition to a powered off state.
segment.target: This metric captures the time from the start of the shutdown phase to the transition to a powered off state.

segment.source: Standby Performance Assessment
segment.target: Standby Performance Assessment

segment.source: This metric captures the time from the start of the suspend phase to the transition to a lower power state (S3).
segment.target: This metric captures the time from the start of the suspend phase to the transition to a lower power state (S3).

segment.source: Hibernate Performance Assessment
segment.target: Hibernate Performance Assessment

segment.source: This metric captures the time from hibernate to the end of writing the hiberfile to disk and the transition to a lower power state (S4).
segment.target: This metric captures the time from hibernate to the end of writing the hiberfile to disk and the transition to a lower power state (S4).

segment.source: Detailed Sub-metrics
segment.target: Detailed Sub-metrics

segment.source: When the metric is expanded, a list of shutdown or suspend sub-phases is presented.
segment.target: When the metric is expanded, a list of shutdown or suspend sub-phases is presented.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The durations of the sub-phases do not necessarily add up to the overall duration.
segment.target: The durations of the sub-phases do not necessarily add up to the overall duration.

segment.source: Typical Influencing Factors
segment.target: Typical Influencing Factors

segment.source: This metric is an overall metric for the system shutdown/suspend.
segment.target: This metric is an overall metric for the system shutdown/suspend.

segment.source: It can be affected by any software components that are running on the shutdown/suspend path.
segment.target: It can be affected by any software components that are running on the shutdown/suspend path.

segment.source: Analysis and Remediation Steps
segment.target: Analysis and Remediation Steps

segment.source: Expand this metric to see the sub-metrics, which provide more information on individual sub-phases of shutdown/suspend.
segment.target: Expand this metric to see the sub-metrics, which provide more information on individual sub-phases of shutdown/suspend.

segment.source: Examine individual sub-phase metrics and issues to find potential delay contributors.
segment.target: Examine individual sub-phase metrics and issues to find potential delay contributors.

segment.source: This metric measures the time that the computer spends shutting down the user session.
segment.target: This metric measures the time that the computer spends shutting down the user session.

segment.source: This phase includes shutting down user-session processes, logging the user off, and notifying subscribers to Winlogon notifications.
segment.target: This phase includes shutting down user-session processes, logging the user off, and notifying subscribers to Winlogon notifications.

segment.source: When the metric is expanded, a list of shutdown or suspend sub-phases is presented.
segment.target: When the metric is expanded, a list of shutdown or suspend sub-phases is presented.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The durations of the sub-phases do not necessarily add up to the overall duration.
segment.target: The durations of the sub-phases do not necessarily add up to the overall duration.

segment.source: This metric is an overall metric for the system shutdown.
segment.target: This metric is an overall metric for the system shutdown.

segment.source: It can be affected by any software components that are running on the shutdown path.
segment.target: It can be affected by any software components that are running on the shutdown path.

segment.source: Analysis and Remediation Steps
segment.target: Analysis and Remediation Steps

segment.source: Expand this metric to see the sub-metrics that provide more information on individual sub-phases of shutdown.
segment.target: Expand this metric to see the sub-metrics that provide more information on individual sub-phases of shutdown.

segment.source: Examine individual sub-phase metrics and issues to find potential delay contributors.
segment.target: Examine individual sub-phase metrics and issues to find potential delay contributors.

segment.source: Boot Performance (Fast Startup)
segment.target: Boot Performance (Fast Startup)

segment.source: When the assessment initiates the user session shutdown, each UI thread in every Graphical User Interface (GUI) application is sent a WMQUERYENDSESSION message.
segment.target: When the assessment initiates the user session shutdown, each UI thread in every Graphical User Interface (GUI) application is sent a WMQUERYENDSESSION message.

segment.source: After Windows receives a response to the WMQUERYENDSESSION message, Windows sends the WMENDSESSION to the same threads.
segment.target: After Windows receives a response to the WMQUERYENDSESSION message, Windows sends the WMENDSESSION to the same threads.

segment.source: If after 5 seconds any application has not responded to these notifications, Windows terminates the application.
segment.target: If after 5 seconds any application has not responded to these notifications, Windows terminates the application.

segment.source: Any application can delay system shutdown by not promptly responding to the messages.
segment.target: Any application can delay system shutdown by not promptly responding to the messages.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If a user initiates the shutdown, a user dialog box displays after the timeout expires.
segment.target: If a user initiates the shutdown, a user dialog box displays after the timeout expires.

segment.source: This dialog shows information about the application that is blocking the shutdown, and allows the user to Force or Cancel the shutdown.
segment.target: This dialog shows information about the application that is blocking the shutdown, and allows the user to Force or Cancel the shutdown.

segment.source: This metric measures the time that the computer spends shutting down all processes in the user session.
segment.target: This metric measures the time that the computer spends shutting down all processes in the user session.

segment.source: Detailed Sub-metrics
segment.target: Detailed Sub-metrics

segment.source: When the metric is expanded, a more detailed view is presented of a set of sub-metrics that measure times each individual process took to respond to shutdown notifications.
segment.target: When the metric is expanded, a more detailed view is presented of a set of sub-metrics that measure times each individual process took to respond to shutdown notifications.

segment.source: The columns show the following information:
segment.target: The columns show the following information:

segment.source: A PID by iteration in the Detail column.
segment.target: A PID by iteration in the Detail column.

segment.source: In the default view, this column might contain the value “Various” because PIDs cannot be aggregated across iterations.
segment.target: In the default view, this column might contain the value “Various” because PIDs cannot be aggregated across iterations.

segment.source: Expand iterations to see individual PIDs.
segment.target: Expand iterations to see individual PIDs.

segment.source: The time that this particular process took during this phase.
segment.target: The time that this particular process took during this phase.

segment.source: Typical Influencing Factors
segment.target: Typical Influencing Factors

segment.source: This metric captures the cumulative time of all running processes that have UI threads to respond to shutdown notification.
segment.target: This metric captures the cumulative time of all running processes that have UI threads to respond to shutdown notification.

segment.source: This metric can be affected by a single process that takes too long, in addition to the cumulative time of all process responses.
segment.target: This metric can be affected by a single process that takes too long, in addition to the cumulative time of all process responses.

segment.source: Each process that has a UI thread can delay system shutdown by delaying its response to the WMQUERYENDSESSION message or WMENDSESSION message.
segment.target: Each process that has a UI thread can delay system shutdown by delaying its response to the WMQUERYENDSESSION message or WMENDSESSION message.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: To impact this metric, a process must be running.
segment.target: To impact this metric, a process must be running.

segment.source: Because this assessment reboots before it collects data for analysis, the running processes are almost exclusively from startup applications or scheduled tasks.
segment.target: Because this assessment reboots before it collects data for analysis, the running processes are almost exclusively from startup applications or scheduled tasks.

segment.source: Analysis and Remediation Steps
segment.target: Analysis and Remediation Steps

segment.source: You can identify processes that most significantly impact this metric by using the Find the Largest Contributor technique.
segment.target: You can identify processes that most significantly impact this metric by using the Find the Largest Contributor technique.

segment.source: If possible, remove applications from the startup path.
segment.target: If possible, remove applications from the startup path.

segment.source: Because the assessment reboots before it performs measurements, the only applications that are running at shutdown are the applications that began at startup.
segment.target: Because the assessment reboots before it performs measurements, the only applications that are running at shutdown are the applications that began at startup.

segment.source: As a best practice, startup applications should be kept to a minimum.
segment.target: As a best practice, startup applications should be kept to a minimum.

segment.source: If an unessential application is causing delays, consider removing it from the list of startup applications.
segment.target: If an unessential application is causing delays, consider removing it from the list of startup applications.

segment.source: Find the possible reasons that responses to WMQUERYENDSESSION message or WMENDSESSION can be delayed, and troubleshoot and fix the underlying issues.
segment.target: Find the possible reasons that responses to WMQUERYENDSESSION message or WMENDSESSION can be delayed, and troubleshoot and fix the underlying issues.

segment.source: See Best Practices for Time-Critical Tasks for a list of common best practices.
segment.target: See Best Practices for Time-Critical Tasks for a list of common best practices.

segment.source: Winlogon Suspend Duration & Winlogon Notifications Duration
segment.target: Winlogon Suspend Duration & Winlogon Notifications Duration

segment.source: Most Applicable to: Winlogon subscriber developers, group policy script owners, system administrators
segment.target: Most Applicable to: Winlogon subscriber developers, group policy script owners, system administrators

segment.source: Relevant Assessments:
segment.target: Relevant Assessments:

segment.source: Boot Performance (Fast Startup)
segment.target: Boot Performance (Fast Startup)

segment.source: Boot Performance (Full Boot)
segment.target: Boot Performance (Full Boot)

segment.source: Standby Performance
segment.target: Standby Performance

segment.source: Hibernate Performance
segment.target: Hibernate Performance

segment.source: This metric measures the time that is spent by Winlogon, including time spent performing subscriber notifications/callbacks.
segment.target: This metric measures the time that is spent by Winlogon, including time spent performing subscriber notifications/callbacks.

segment.source: For the Boot Performance (Fast Startup) scenario, the Winlogon Notifications metric in Windows Assessment Console reflects the cumulative time that is spent processing all Winlogon subscriber notifications and callbacks.
segment.target: For the Boot Performance (Fast Startup) scenario, the Winlogon Notifications metric in Windows Assessment Console reflects the cumulative time that is spent processing all Winlogon subscriber notifications and callbacks.

segment.source: However, to provide context in the Windows® Performance Analyzer (WPA) timeline, the Winlogon Notifications activity starts with the first subscriber notification/callback and ends with the last.
segment.target: However, to provide context in the Windows® Performance Analyzer (WPA) timeline, the Winlogon Notifications activity starts with the first subscriber notification/callback and ends with the last.

segment.source: The time that is spent processing each notification is represented by individual child activities.
segment.target: The time that is spent processing each notification is represented by individual child activities.

segment.source: Boot Performance (Fast Startup) is the only assessment that provides additional sub-metrics for this metric.
segment.target: Boot Performance (Fast Startup) is the only assessment that provides additional sub-metrics for this metric.

segment.source: During suspend, Winlogon issues synchronous subscriber notifications to registered subscribers for the following four notification types:
segment.target: During suspend, Winlogon issues synchronous subscriber notifications to registered subscribers for the following four notification types:

segment.source: Terminate Session
segment.target: Terminate Session

segment.source: End Shell
segment.target: End Shell

segment.source: Logoff
segment.target: Logoff

segment.source: Create Session
segment.target: Create Session

segment.source: When the metric is expanded, these four notification types are presented as sub-metrics.
segment.target: When the metric is expanded, these four notification types are presented as sub-metrics.

segment.source: Each of these types has a list of subscribers (for example, profiles and GPClient) as additional sub-metrics, and each subscriber lists the specific instances of Connect to Subscriber and Call Subscriber for that subscriber.
segment.target: Each of these types has a list of subscribers (for example, profiles and GPClient) as additional sub-metrics, and each subscriber lists the specific instances of Connect to Subscriber and Call Subscriber for that subscriber.

segment.source: In any scenario, Winlogon subscribers can delay shutdown/suspend by taking too long to process these notifications.
segment.target: In any scenario, Winlogon subscribers can delay shutdown/suspend by taking too long to process these notifications.

segment.source: For example, a profile service (Profiles) must synchronize the user profile if the Roaming (Remote) Profiles feature is enabled on the computer.
segment.target: For example, a profile service (Profiles) must synchronize the user profile if the Roaming (Remote) Profiles feature is enabled on the computer.

segment.source: As another example, a Group Policy client (GPClient) might be configured by a system or domain policy to perform certain tasks at user logoff.
segment.target: As another example, a Group Policy client (GPClient) might be configured by a system or domain policy to perform certain tasks at user logoff.

segment.source: These tasks are typically configured by a system or domain administrator.
segment.target: These tasks are typically configured by a system or domain administrator.

segment.source: Typical Influencing Factors
segment.target: Typical Influencing Factors

segment.source: When you examine this metric, you should focus on the Winlogon Subscribers.
segment.target: When you examine this metric, you should focus on the Winlogon Subscribers.

segment.source: Analysis and Remediation Steps
segment.target: Analysis and Remediation Steps

segment.source: Examine times of individual subscriber operations.
segment.target: Examine times of individual subscriber operations.

segment.source: Specific issues are usually generated for subscribers that have longer durations.
segment.target: Specific issues are usually generated for subscribers that have longer durations.

segment.source: Open WPA to the time interval of a subscriber for more insight.
segment.target: Open WPA to the time interval of a subscriber for more insight.

segment.source: For example, if a GPClient subscriber call takes 10 seconds, an examination of that period in WPA can reveal that a certain custom script runs for 9 seconds out of 10.
segment.target: For example, if a GPClient subscriber call takes 10 seconds, an examination of that period in WPA can reveal that a certain custom script runs for 9 seconds out of 10.

segment.source: This points out that the script is a highly-probable root cause of the delay.
segment.target: This points out that the script is a highly-probable root cause of the delay.

segment.source: This metric measures the time that the computer spends notifying processes of the impending power state change.
segment.target: This metric measures the time that the computer spends notifying processes of the impending power state change.

segment.source: During this phase, the Client/Server Runtime Server Subsystem (Csrss.exe) broadcasts WMPOWERBROADCAST window messages together with the event type of PBTAPMSUSPEND to every application that owns a window.
segment.target: During this phase, the Client/Server Runtime Server Subsystem (Csrss.exe) broadcasts WMPOWERBROADCAST window messages together with the event type of PBTAPMSUSPEND to every application that owns a window.

segment.source: The system might also power off the monitor.
segment.target: The system might also power off the monitor.

segment.source: This activity can be seen in the WPA Activities graph as a large gap between consecutive processes that are being suspended.
segment.target: This activity can be seen in the WPA Activities graph as a large gap between consecutive processes that are being suspended.

segment.source: One second or more is expected to power off the monitor.
segment.target: One second or more is expected to power off the monitor.

segment.source: This is a necessary stage during suspend/shut down, and it should not be considered a performance bottleneck for this metric.
segment.target: This is a necessary stage during suspend/shut down, and it should not be considered a performance bottleneck for this metric.

segment.source: Look at the CPU Usage (Sampled) graph during this time to show CPU utilization in the csrss.exe process on the following stack:
segment.target: Look at the CPU Usage (Sampled) graph during this time to show CPU utilization in the csrss.exe process on the following stack:

segment.source: Gaps in Suspend Processes because of CPU consumption on other stacks, or delays without CPU utilization on the current stack, can suggest areas to investigate further.
segment.target: Gaps in Suspend Processes because of CPU consumption on other stacks, or delays without CPU utilization on the current stack, can suggest areas to investigate further.

segment.target: When the metric is expanded, a more detailed phase view is presented, with a set of sub-metrics that measure the times that each process took to respond to suspend notifications.

segment.source: The columns show the following information:
segment.target: The columns show the following information:

segment.source: A PID by iteration in the Detail column.
segment.target: A PID by iteration in the Detail column.

segment.source: In the default view, this column might contain the value “Various” because PIDs cannot be aggregated across iterations.
segment.target: In the default view, this column might contain the value “Various” because PIDs cannot be aggregated across iterations.

segment.source: Expand iterations to see individual PIDs.

segment.source: The time that this particular process took during this phase.
segment.target: The time that this particular process took during this phase.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If an application has more than one window, the same process can receive more than one notification.
segment.target: If an application has more than one window, the same process can receive more than one notification.

segment.source: Typical Influencing Factors
segment.target: Typical Influencing Factors

segment.source: Each application has the ability to delay system shutdown by delaying its response to the WMPOWERBROADCAST message with PBTAPMSUSPEND event type.
segment.target: Each application has the ability to delay system shutdown by delaying its response to the WMPOWERBROADCAST message with PBTAPMSUSPEND event type.

segment.source: Because this metric captures the cumulative time that all windows GUI processes take to respond to the suspend notification, this metric can be affected by a single process that takes too long, in addition to a cumulative time of all process responses.
segment.target: Because this metric captures the cumulative time that all windows GUI processes take to respond to the suspend notification, this metric can be affected by a single process that takes too long, in addition to a cumulative time of all process responses.

segment.source: Note that the process must be running to impact this metric; because the Boot Performance (Fast Startup) assessment reboots before it collects data for analysis, these processes come almost exclusively from startup applications or scheduled tasks.
segment.target: Note that the process must be running to impact this metric; because the Boot Performance (Fast Startup) assessment reboots before it collects data for analysis, these processes come almost exclusively from startup applications or scheduled tasks.

segment.source: Analysis and Remediation Steps
segment.target: Analysis and Remediation Steps

segment.source: Identify the processes that most significantly impact this metric.
segment.target: Identify the processes that most significantly impact this metric.

segment.source: In Windows Assessment Console, expand the Suspend Processes Duration metric to get the details for this phase.
segment.target: In Windows Assessment Console, expand the Suspend Processes Duration metric to get the details for this phase.

segment.source: In the Process list for this phase, sort the Duration in descending order and look for the largest contributors.
segment.target: In the Process list for this phase, sort the Duration in descending order and look for the largest contributors.

segment.source: If possible, remove applications from the startup path.
segment.target: If possible, remove applications from the startup path.

segment.source: As a best practice, startup applications should be kept to a minimum.
segment.target: As a best practice, startup applications should be kept to a minimum.

segment.source: If an unessential application is causing delays, consider removing it from the list of startup applications.
segment.target: If an unessential application is causing delays, consider removing it from the list of startup applications.

segment.source: Troubleshooting and fixing issues with that significantly impact the startup path requires deep analysis of application delays.
segment.target: Troubleshooting and fixing issues with that significantly impact the startup path requires deep analysis of application delays.

segment.source: See Best Practices for Time-Critical Tasks for a list of common best practices.
segment.target: See Best Practices for Time-Critical Tasks for a list of common best practices.

segment.source: Hibernate Performance
segment.target: Hibernate Performance

segment.source: This metric measures the time that the computer spends notifying services of the impending power state change.
segment.target: This metric measures the time that the computer spends notifying services of the impending power state change.

segment.source: All services that register to receive power management events (SERVICEACCEPTPOWEREVENT) receive suspend notifications.
segment.target: All services that register to receive power management events (SERVICEACCEPTPOWEREVENT) receive suspend notifications.

segment.source: Because these notifications are sent serially, any delay in a service directly contributes to the overall shutdown/suspend duration.
segment.target: Because these notifications are sent serially, any delay in a service directly contributes to the overall shutdown/suspend duration.

segment.source: A 30 second timeout is enforced (on a per-service basis) to process this notification; after this timeout, the system moves on to the next phase.
segment.target: A 30 second timeout is enforced (on a per-service basis) to process this notification; after this timeout, the system moves on to the next phase.

segment.source: Because registering for this notification is optional, no specific action by the service is required by the OS.
segment.target: Because registering for this notification is optional, no specific action by the service is required by the OS.

segment.source: Detailed Sub-metrics
segment.target: Detailed Sub-metrics

segment.source: When the metric is expanded, a more detailed phase view is presented with a list of individual services and their corresponding durations.
segment.target: When the metric is expanded, a more detailed phase view is presented with a list of individual services and their corresponding durations.

segment.source: Typical Influencing Factors
segment.target: Typical Influencing Factors

segment.source: This metric captures the cumulative time that all services take to respond to a power query.
segment.target: This metric captures the cumulative time that all services take to respond to a power query.

segment.source: This metric can be affected by a single process that takes too long, in addition to the cumulative time of all process responses.
segment.target: This metric can be affected by a single process that takes too long, in addition to the cumulative time of all process responses.

segment.source: Most services are not required to do any significant work in response to standby and hibernate power notifications.
segment.target: Most services are not required to do any significant work in response to standby and hibernate power notifications.

segment.source: From a service’s perspective, fast startup is similar to hibernate.
segment.target: From a service’s perspective, fast startup is similar to hibernate.

segment.source: Analysis and Remediation Steps
segment.target: Analysis and Remediation Steps

segment.source: Identify a service that significantly impacts this metric.
segment.target: Identify a service that significantly impacts this metric.

segment.source: Longer delays in service responses generally produce issues that are specific to a given service.
segment.target: Longer delays in service responses generally produce issues that are specific to a given service.

segment.source: When such an issue is generated, you can follow the link inside the issue to see advanced issue details.
segment.target: When such an issue is generated, you can follow the link inside the issue to see advanced issue details.

segment.source: When an issue is not generated, subsequent analysis in WPA is required.
segment.target: When an issue is not generated, subsequent analysis in WPA is required.

segment.source: This additional analysis is beyond the scope of this document.
segment.target: This additional analysis is beyond the scope of this document.

segment.source: For more information about common best practices, see Best Practices for Time-Critical Tasks.
segment.target: For more information about common best practices, see Best Practices for Time-Critical Tasks.

segment.source: This metric measures the time that the Windows Superfetch service spends preparing the memory state for the subsequent boot/resume.
segment.target: This metric measures the time that the Windows Superfetch service spends preparing the memory state for the subsequent boot/resume.

segment.source: Superfetch pre-fetches data that is frequently accessed on startup, and stores it either in the hiberfile (for Boot Performance (Fast Startup) and Hibernate Performance) or main memory (Standby Performance) to avoid excessive disk accesses on resume.
segment.target: Superfetch pre-fetches data that is frequently accessed on startup, and stores it either in the hiberfile (for Boot Performance (Fast Startup) and Hibernate Performance) or main memory (Standby Performance) to avoid excessive disk accesses on resume.

segment.source: This feature accelerates the resume process.
segment.target: This feature accelerates the resume process.

segment.source: Typical Influencing Factors
segment.target: Typical Influencing Factors

segment.source: During this phase, the Superfetch service accesses data that is read during startup.
segment.target: During this phase, the Superfetch service accesses data that is read during startup.

segment.source: The duration of this phase is directly influenced by the amount of data that must be read during startup by startup applications, services, credential providers, and so on.
segment.target: The duration of this phase is directly influenced by the amount of data that must be read during startup by startup applications, services, credential providers, and so on.

segment.source: Analysis and Remediation Steps
segment.target: Analysis and Remediation Steps

segment.source: This phase requires advanced analysis that is not included in this document.
segment.target: This phase requires advanced analysis that is not included in this document.

segment.source: During the shutdown/suspend phase, every device driver is sent a power IRP that has a IRPMNQUERYPOWER minor code and a power state (S4 for Boot Performance (Fast Startup)/Hibernate Performance, S3 for Standby Performance).
segment.target: During the shutdown/suspend phase, every device driver is sent a power IRP that has a IRPMNQUERYPOWER minor code and a power state (S4 for Boot Performance (Fast Startup)/Hibernate Performance, S3 for Standby Performance).

segment.source: This metric measures the duration of all drivers that process the query power IRP.
segment.target: This metric measures the duration of all drivers that process the query power IRP.

segment.source: Each driver can delay system shutdown by not promptly handling the IRP.
segment.target: Each driver can delay system shutdown by not promptly handling the IRP.

segment.source: Detailed Sub-metrics
segment.target: Detailed Sub-metrics

segment.source: When the metric is expanded, a more detailed phase view is presented with a list of devices and their corresponding durations.
segment.target: When the metric is expanded, a more detailed phase view is presented with a list of devices and their corresponding durations.

segment.source: Typical Influencing Factors
segment.target: Typical Influencing Factors

segment.source: This metric captures the cumulative time that all drivers take to respond to power queries.
segment.target: This metric captures the cumulative time that all drivers take to respond to power queries.

segment.source: This metric can be affected by a single driver that takes too long to respond, in addition to the cumulative time of all driver responses.
segment.target: This metric can be affected by a single driver that takes too long to respond, in addition to the cumulative time of all driver responses.

segment.source: Analysis and Remediation Steps
segment.target: Analysis and Remediation Steps

segment.source: You can identify a driver or drivers that significantly impact this metric by looking at the sub-metrics.
segment.target: You can identify a driver or drivers that significantly impact this metric by looking at the sub-metrics.

segment.source: Longer delays in the driver response durations usually produce issues that are specific to a given driver.
segment.target: Longer delays in the driver response durations usually produce issues that are specific to a given driver.

segment.source: When such an issue is generated, follow the link inside the issue to see advanced issue details.
segment.target: When such an issue is generated, follow the link inside the issue to see advanced issue details.

segment.source: When an issue is not generated, subsequent analysis in WPA is required; this is beyond the scope of this document.
segment.target: When an issue is not generated, subsequent analysis in WPA is required; this is beyond the scope of this document.

segment.source: See Best Practices for Time-Critical Tasks for a list of common best practices.
segment.target: See Best Practices for Time-Critical Tasks for a list of common best practices.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If a driver owns a power policy for a device, it generates a Device Power IRP in response to receiving a System Power IRP.
segment.target: If a driver owns a power policy for a device, it generates a Device Power IRP in response to receiving a System Power IRP.

segment.source: Drivers should not wait to complete the System IRP until the Device IRP is completed because that wait can prevent other devices from receiving their System IRPs.
segment.target: Drivers should not wait to complete the System IRP until the Device IRP is completed because that wait can prevent other devices from receiving their System IRPs.

segment.source: This series of waits cause serialization delays and increases the overall suspend time.
segment.target: This series of waits cause serialization delays and increases the overall suspend time.

segment.source: This metric measures the time that the computer spends writing to the registry and saving any other modified pages to secondary storage.
segment.target: This metric measures the time that the computer spends writing to the registry and saving any other modified pages to secondary storage.

segment.source: Typical Influencing Factors
segment.target: Typical Influencing Factors

segment.source: The time that this metric represents depends on the amount of data that needs to be flushed.
segment.target: The time that this metric represents depends on the amount of data that needs to be flushed.

segment.source: Analysis and Remediation Steps
segment.target: Analysis and Remediation Steps

segment.source: Identifying the processes that are responsible for this data requires advanced analysis that is beyond the scope of this document; however, any process that writes large amounts of data directly before shutdown are suspect.
segment.target: Identifying the processes that are responsible for this data requires advanced analysis that is beyond the scope of this document; however, any process that writes large amounts of data directly before shutdown are suspect.

segment.source: Examples are: an application that wrote a multi-megabyte data file by using cached I/O directly before exiting, or a service that modifies large amounts of file-mapped memory at shutdown time.
segment.target: Examples are: an application that wrote a multi-megabyte data file by using cached I/O directly before exiting, or a service that modifies large amounts of file-mapped memory at shutdown time.

segment.source: During the shutdown phase of the Boot Performance (Fast Startup) scenario, every device driver is sent a power (IRPMJPOWER) I/O (IRP that has IRPMNSETPOWER minor code and a power state (S4 for Boot Performance (Fast Startup) or Hibernate Performance, S3 for Standby Performance).
segment.target: During the shutdown phase of the Boot Performance (Fast Startup) scenario, every device driver is sent a power (IRPMJPOWER) I/O (IRP that has IRPMNSETPOWER minor code and a power state (S4 for Boot Performance (Fast Startup) or Hibernate Performance, S3 for Standby Performance).

segment.source: This metric measures the time that is required for all drivers to process the set power IRP.
segment.target: This metric measures the time that is required for all drivers to process the set power IRP.

segment.source: When device drivers process this IRP, they save appropriate device context (if required), and put the device in the appropriate state for sleep or hibernate.
segment.target: When device drivers process this IRP, they save appropriate device context (if required), and put the device in the appropriate state for sleep or hibernate.

segment.source: Each driver can delay system shutdown by not promptly handling the IRP.
segment.target: Each driver can delay system shutdown by not promptly handling the IRP.

segment.source: This metric captures the cumulative time that all drivers take to respond to a power query.
segment.target: This metric captures the cumulative time that all drivers take to respond to a power query.

segment.source: This metric can be affected by a single driver that takes too long to respond in addition to the cumulative time of all responses.
segment.target: This metric can be affected by a single driver that takes too long to respond in addition to the cumulative time of all responses.

segment.target: If a driver owns a power policy for a device, it generates a Device Power IRP in response to receiving a System Power IRP.

segment.source: Drivers should not wait to complete the System IRP until the Device IRP is completed because that wait can prevent other devices from receiving their System IRPs.

segment.source: Hiberfile Write Duration
segment.target: Hiberfile Write Duration

segment.source: Most Applicable to: Application developers, Windows service developers, Driver developers
segment.target: Most Applicable to: Application developers, Windows service developers, Driver developers

segment.source: Relevant Assessments:
segment.target: Relevant Assessments:

segment.source: Boot Performance (Fast Startup)
segment.target: Boot Performance (Fast Startup)

segment.source: Hibernate Performance
segment.target: Hibernate Performance

segment.source: This metric measures the time that the system spends writing the relevant contents of main memory to secondary storage; specifically, into hiberfile.sys file that is usually found in the root directory of the system drive.
segment.target: This metric measures the time that the system spends writing the relevant contents of main memory to secondary storage; specifically, into hiberfile.sys file that is usually found in the root directory of the system drive.

segment.source: Detailed Sub-metrics
segment.target: Detailed Sub-metrics

segment.source: When the metric is expanded, the size of the hiberfile is shown in Kilobytes.
segment.target: When the metric is expanded, the size of the hiberfile is shown in Kilobytes.

segment.source: Typical Influencing Factors
segment.target: Typical Influencing Factors

segment.source: The time it takes to write the hiberfile is directly proportional to the amount of data that needs to be written.
segment.target: The time it takes to write the hiberfile is directly proportional to the amount of data that needs to be written.

segment.source: This data consists of memory that is in use by the operating system, drivers, and services, in addition to any data that the system must read during system resume (as identified during the Superfetch Prepare Memory phase).
segment.target: This data consists of memory that is in use by the operating system, drivers, and services, in addition to any data that the system must read during system resume (as identified during the Superfetch Prepare Memory phase).

segment.source: A driver that uses large amounts of memory can influence this metric by having the memory manager write data into the hiberfile.
segment.target: A driver that uses large amounts of memory can influence this metric by having the memory manager write data into the hiberfile.

segment.source: Or, a startup application can cause large amounts of data to be read on the resume path.
segment.target: Or, a startup application can cause large amounts of data to be read on the resume path.

segment.source: In these cases, the Superfetch service ensures that data is included into the hiberfile to avoid slow random faulting on the resume path.
segment.target: In these cases, the Superfetch service ensures that data is included into the hiberfile to avoid slow random faulting on the resume path.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Hard drive physical performance characteristics, such as sequential write throughput, also affects this metric.
segment.target: Hard drive physical performance characteristics, such as sequential write throughput, also affects this metric.

segment.source: Analysis and Remediation Steps
segment.target: Analysis and Remediation Steps

segment.source: Identifying the specific components that contribute to the longer hiberfile write durations requires detailed memory analysis and is beyond the scope of this document.
segment.target: Identifying the specific components that contribute to the longer hiberfile write durations requires detailed memory analysis and is beyond the scope of this document.

segment.source: However, each running driver and service can contribute to this metric by retaining large memory allocations.
segment.target: However, each running driver and service can contribute to this metric by retaining large memory allocations.

segment.source: The number and footprint of the startup applications, and of other components that read data during startup, can also influence this metric.
segment.target: The number and footprint of the startup applications, and of other components that read data during startup, can also influence this metric.

segment.source: This metric measures the time that the platform firmware spends identifying and initializing hardware devices and running a power-on self-test (POST).
segment.target: This metric measures the time that the platform firmware spends identifying and initializing hardware devices and running a power-on self-test (POST).

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: BIOS initialization happens before the operating system receives control.
segment.target: BIOS initialization happens before the operating system receives control.

segment.source: The assessment cannot thoroughly inspect the phase and can only report on its duration.
segment.target: The assessment cannot thoroughly inspect the phase and can only report on its duration.

segment.source: Detailed Sub-metrics
segment.target: Detailed Sub-metrics

segment.source: Boot Performance (Fast Startup) is the only scenario to provide additional sub-metrics for this metric.
segment.target: Boot Performance (Fast Startup) is the only scenario to provide additional sub-metrics for this metric.

segment.source: For systems that contain BIOS that support the latest Advanced Configuration and Power Interface (ACPI) standard (ACPI 5.0), this metric can be expanded to show the POST time that is reported by the Firmware Performance Data Table (FPDT).
segment.target: For systems that contain BIOS that support the latest Advanced Configuration and Power Interface (ACPI) standard (ACPI 5.0), this metric can be expanded to show the POST time that is reported by the Firmware Performance Data Table (FPDT).

segment.source: This is an alternate measurement for the BIOS Initialization duration, which is reported by kernel instrumentation.
segment.target: This is an alternate measurement for the BIOS Initialization duration, which is reported by kernel instrumentation.

segment.source: Typical Influencing Factors
segment.target: Typical Influencing Factors

segment.source: The boot order that is set for the system can be a significant source of delay during BIOS Initialization.
segment.target: The boot order that is set for the system can be a significant source of delay during BIOS Initialization.

segment.source: This order can require the system to check for bootable optical, floppy, USB, or other hard drives before it loads Windows.
segment.target: This order can require the system to check for bootable optical, floppy, USB, or other hard drives before it loads Windows.

segment.source: PXE Boot (network/remote boot) can also be set as part of the boot order; if this is enabled, it can significantly affect the delay.
segment.target: PXE Boot (network/remote boot) can also be set as part of the boot order; if this is enabled, it can significantly affect the delay.

segment.source: Some BIOS configurations also have advanced diagnostics or verification modes that can take longer to complete.
segment.target: Some BIOS configurations also have advanced diagnostics or verification modes that can take longer to complete.

segment.source: Analysis and Remediation Steps
segment.target: Analysis and Remediation Steps

segment.source: No additional information is captured for the BIOS phase.
segment.target: No additional information is captured for the BIOS phase.

segment.source: Typical influencing factors such as enabled PXE boot should be checked.
segment.target: Typical influencing factors such as enabled PXE boot should be checked.

segment.source: The BIOS manufacturer should be consulted when you need to triage or alter these settings.
segment.target: The BIOS manufacturer should be consulted when you need to triage or alter these settings.

segment.source: A deeper investigation of the BIOS Initialization phase is beyond the scope of this document.
segment.target: A deeper investigation of the BIOS Initialization phase is beyond the scope of this document.

segment.source: This metric measures the time to find and start Winload.exe, the operating system loader, on the Windows boot partition.
segment.target: This metric measures the time to find and start Winload.exe, the operating system loader, on the Windows boot partition.

segment.source: Typical Influencing Factors
segment.target: Typical Influencing Factors

segment.source: This metric can be affected by BitLocker operations, especially if a PIN is required for BitLocker to start.
segment.target: This metric can be affected by BitLocker operations, especially if a PIN is required for BitLocker to start.

segment.source: Analysis and Remediation Steps
segment.target: Analysis and Remediation Steps

segment.source: Use a BitLocker unlock method that does not require manual PIN entry.
segment.target: Use a BitLocker unlock method that does not require manual PIN entry.

segment.target: Hiberfile Read Duration

segment.source: Most Applicable to: Application developers, Windows service developers, driver developers
segment.target: Most Applicable to: Application developers, Windows service developers, driver developers

segment.source: Relevant Assessments:

segment.source: Hibernate Performance
segment.target: Hibernate Performance

segment.source: This metric measures the time that the system spends reading the contents of the hiberfile into main memory.
segment.target: This metric measures the time that the system spends reading the contents of the hiberfile into main memory.

segment.source: Detailed Sub-metrics
segment.target: Detailed Sub-metrics

segment.source: When the metric is expanded, the size of the hiberfile (in Kilobytes) is shown.
segment.target: When the metric is expanded, the size of the hiberfile (in Kilobytes) is shown.

segment.source: Typical Influencing Factors
segment.target: Typical Influencing Factors

segment.source: The time that it takes to read the hiberfile is directly proportional to the amount of data that must be read.
segment.target: The time that it takes to read the hiberfile is directly proportional to the amount of data that must be read.

segment.source: This data consists of data in memory that is used by the operating system, drivers, and services, in addition to data that the system uses for system resume (identified during the Superfetch Prepare Memory phase of shutdown/suspend).
segment.target: This data consists of data in memory that is used by the operating system, drivers, and services, in addition to data that the system uses for system resume (identified during the Superfetch Prepare Memory phase of shutdown/suspend).

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Hard drive physical performance characteristics, such as sequential read throughput, also affects this metric.
segment.target: Hard drive physical performance characteristics, such as sequential read throughput, also affects this metric.

segment.source: Analysis and Remediation Steps
segment.target: Analysis and Remediation Steps

segment.source: Identifying the specific components that contribute to longer hiberfile read durations requires detailed memory analysis and is beyond the scope of this document.
segment.target: Identifying the specific components that contribute to longer hiberfile read durations requires detailed memory analysis and is beyond the scope of this document.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Each running driver and service can contribute to this metric by retaining large memory allocations.
segment.target: Each running driver and service can contribute to this metric by retaining large memory allocations.

segment.source: The number and footprint of startup applications and other components that read data during startup also influence this metric.
segment.target: The number and footprint of startup applications and other components that read data during startup also influence this metric.

segment.target: Relevant Assessments:

segment.source: Boot Performance (Fast Startup)
segment.target: Boot Performance (Fast Startup)

segment.source: Standby Performance
segment.target: Standby Performance

segment.source: Hibernate Performance
segment.target: Hibernate Performance

segment.source: During shutdown/suspend, every device driver is sent a power (IRPMJPOWER) IRP that has an IRPMNSETPOWER minor code and working power state.
segment.target: During shutdown/suspend, every device driver is sent a power (IRPMJPOWER) IRP that has an IRPMNSETPOWER minor code and working power state.

segment.source: Device drivers subsequently send Device Power IRPs to corresponding devices.
segment.target: Device drivers subsequently send Device Power IRPs to corresponding devices.

segment.source: This metric measures the time for all drivers to process the set power IRP.
segment.target: This metric measures the time for all drivers to process the set power IRP.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Drivers should not retain the System Power IRP during this phase.
segment.target: Drivers should not retain the System Power IRP during this phase.

segment.source: Each driver can delay system startup by not promptly handling the system power IRP.
segment.target: Each driver can delay system startup by not promptly handling the system power IRP.

segment.source: Detailed Sub-metrics
segment.target: Detailed Sub-metrics

segment.source: When the metric is expanded, a more detailed phase view is presented with a list of devices and their corresponding durations.
segment.target: When the metric is expanded, a more detailed phase view is presented with a list of devices and their corresponding durations.

segment.source: Typical Influencing Factors
segment.target: Typical Influencing Factors

segment.source: This metric captures the cumulative time that all drivers take to respond to an IRPMNSETPOWER power request.
segment.target: This metric captures the cumulative time that all drivers take to respond to an IRPMNSETPOWER power request.

segment.source: This metric can be affected by a single driver that takes too much time, in addition to the cumulative time of all driver responses.
segment.target: This metric can be affected by a single driver that takes too much time, in addition to the cumulative time of all driver responses.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If a driver owns a power policy for a device, it generates a Device Power IRP in response to receiving a System Power IRP.
segment.target: If a driver owns a power policy for a device, it generates a Device Power IRP in response to receiving a System Power IRP.

segment.source: Drivers should not wait to complete the System IRP until the Device IRP is completed because that wait can prevent other devices from receiving their System IRPs.
segment.target: Drivers should not wait to complete the System IRP until the Device IRP is completed because that wait can prevent other devices from receiving their System IRPs.

segment.source: This series of waits cause serialization delays and increases the overall suspend time.
segment.target: This series of waits cause serialization delays and increases the overall suspend time.

segment.source: Analysis and Remediation Steps
segment.target: Analysis and Remediation Steps

segment.source: You can identify a driver or drivers that significantly impact this metric by looking at the sub-metrics.
segment.target: You can identify a driver or drivers that significantly impact this metric by looking at the sub-metrics.

segment.source: Long delays in the driver responses usually produce issues that are specific to a given driver.
segment.target: Long delays in the driver responses usually produce issues that are specific to a given driver.

segment.source: When such an issue is generated, follow the link inside the issue to see advanced issue details.
segment.target: When such an issue is generated, follow the link inside the issue to see advanced issue details.

segment.source: When an issue is not generated, subsequent analysis in WPA is required; this is beyond the scope of this document.
segment.target: When an issue is not generated, subsequent analysis in WPA is required; this is beyond the scope of this document.

segment.source: See Best Practices for Time-Critical Tasks.
segment.target: See Best Practices for Time-Critical Tasks.

segment.target: Additional Information

segment.source: Operating System Selection Menu Duration
segment.target: Operating System Selection Menu Duration

segment.source: Most Applicable to: System administrators
segment.target: Most Applicable to: System administrators

segment.source: Relevant Assessments:
segment.target: Relevant Assessments:

segment.source: Boot Performance (Fast Startup)
segment.target: Boot Performance (Fast Startup)

segment.source: This metric measures the time that it takes for the operating system selection menu to make its default selection.
segment.target: This metric measures the time that it takes for the operating system selection menu to make its default selection.

segment.source: By default, a selection is made after 30 seconds (in the absence of user interaction).
segment.target: By default, a selection is made after 30 seconds (in the absence of user interaction).

segment.source: Typical Influencing Factors
segment.target: Typical Influencing Factors

segment.source: This metric is unaffected by system behavior.
segment.target: This metric is unaffected by system behavior.

segment.source: This metric is reported only on systems that have multiple operating systems installed, and it will always report 30 seconds if no user interaction is performed.
segment.target: This metric is reported only on systems that have multiple operating systems installed, and it will always report 30 seconds if no user interaction is performed.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Although system behavior does not affect the duration of this metric, the boot process has many asynchronous processes that can run during this time.
segment.target: Although system behavior does not affect the duration of this metric, the boot process has many asynchronous processes that can run during this time.

segment.source: These processes can affect the results for activities that occur after the default selection is made, because some of the work that is normally performed during these times might already be completed.
segment.target: These processes can affect the results for activities that occur after the default selection is made, because some of the work that is normally performed during these times might already be completed.

segment.source: Analysis and Remediation Steps
segment.target: Analysis and Remediation Steps

segment.source: Remove all installed operating systems other except for the one that is being analyzed.
segment.target: Remove all installed operating systems other except for the one that is being analyzed.

segment.source: To view the list of currently installed operating systems (including settings that affect this menu), run msconfig.exe at a command prompt and then choose the Boot tab.
segment.target: To view the list of currently installed operating systems (including settings that affect this menu), run msconfig.exe at a command prompt and then choose the Boot tab.

segment.source: Winlogon Resume Duration
segment.target: Winlogon Resume Duration

segment.source: Most Applicable to: Winlogon subscriber developers, group policy script owners, system administrators, credential provider writers
segment.target: Most Applicable to: Winlogon subscriber developers, group policy script owners, system administrators, credential provider writers

segment.source: Relevant Assessments:
segment.target: Relevant Assessments:

segment.source: Boot Performance (Fast Startup)
segment.target: Boot Performance (Fast Startup)

segment.source: Hibernate Performance
segment.target: Hibernate Performance

segment.source: This metric represents a timespan of multiple Winlogon callouts and operations, such as interaction with Winlogon subscribers.
segment.target: This metric represents a timespan of multiple Winlogon callouts and operations, such as interaction with Winlogon subscribers.

segment.source: This metric is not the accumulated time that is spent in subscriber notifications, and it should not be treated as such.
segment.target: This metric is not the accumulated time that is spent in subscriber notifications, and it should not be treated as such.

segment.source: Detailed Sub-metrics
segment.target: Detailed Sub-metrics

segment.source: Boot Performance (Fast Startup) is the only assessment that provides additional sub-metrics for this metric.
segment.target: Boot Performance (Fast Startup) is the only assessment that provides additional sub-metrics for this metric.

segment.source: When the metric is expanded, a more detailed phase view is presented that includes the times incurred by each of the Winlogon subscribers.
segment.target: When the metric is expanded, a more detailed phase view is presented that includes the times incurred by each of the Winlogon subscribers.

segment.source: During resume, Winlogon issues synchronous subscriber notifications to registered subscribers for the following two notification types:
segment.target: During resume, Winlogon issues synchronous subscriber notifications to registered subscribers for the following two notification types:

segment.source: Logon
segment.target: Logon

segment.source: Start Shell
segment.target: Start Shell

segment.source: When it is expanded, these two notification types are presented as sub-metrics.
segment.target: When it is expanded, these two notification types are presented as sub-metrics.

segment.source: Each of these types has a list of subscribers (for example, profiles or GPClient) as additional sub-metrics.
segment.target: Each of these types has a list of subscribers (for example, profiles or GPClient) as additional sub-metrics.

segment.source: Each subscriber lists the specific instances of Connect to Subscriber and Call Subscriber for that subscriber.
segment.target: Each subscriber lists the specific instances of Connect to Subscriber and Call Subscriber for that subscriber.

segment.source: For all scenarios, Winlogon subscribers can delay shutdown by taking too long to process these notifications.
segment.target: For all scenarios, Winlogon subscribers can delay shutdown by taking too long to process these notifications.

segment.source: For example, a profile service (Profiles) must synchronize the user profile if the Roaming (Remote) Profiles feature is enabled on that computer.
segment.target: For example, a profile service (Profiles) must synchronize the user profile if the Roaming (Remote) Profiles feature is enabled on that computer.

segment.source: Or, a group policy client (GPClient) might be configured by a system or domain policy to perform certain tasks upon user logon.
segment.target: Or, a group policy client (GPClient) might be configured by a system or domain policy to perform certain tasks upon user logon.

segment.source: These tasks are typically configured by a system or domain administrator, and generally run non-Microsoft owned scripts.
segment.target: These tasks are typically configured by a system or domain administrator, and generally run non-Microsoft owned scripts.

segment.source: Typical Influencing Factors
segment.target: Typical Influencing Factors

segment.source: When you examine this metric, you should focus on the Winlogon subscribers that process the notifications for Logon and Start Shell.
segment.target: When you examine this metric, you should focus on the Winlogon subscribers that process the notifications for Logon and Start Shell.

segment.source: Analysis and Remediation Steps
segment.target: Analysis and Remediation Steps

segment.source: Examine times of individual subscriber operations.
segment.target: Examine times of individual subscriber operations.

segment.source: Specific issues are usually generated for longer subscriber durations.
segment.target: Specific issues are usually generated for longer subscriber durations.

segment.source: You can also gain insight by opening WPA to the time interval of a subscriber.
segment.target: You can also gain insight by opening WPA to the time interval of a subscriber.

segment.source: For example, if a GPClient subscriber call takes 10 seconds, an examination of that duration in WPA can reveal that a certain custom script is running for 9 seconds out of 10.
segment.target: For example, if a GPClient subscriber call takes 10 seconds, an examination of that duration in WPA can reveal that a certain custom script is running for 9 seconds out of 10.

segment.source: This can be seen in the Process Lifetimes graph.
segment.target: This can be seen in the Process Lifetimes graph.

segment.source: It indicates that this script is a probable root cause for the delay.
segment.target: It indicates that this script is a probable root cause for the delay.

segment.source: Additional Information
segment.target: Additional Information
